title: the online world become toxic
story: The online world has become toxic for too many of us - we need changeAfter a three year delay, the Conservatives’ promised draft Bill has finally been published but it’s weak, ineffective and won’t do the job we need it to do, writes Labours Jo Stevens MP, Shadow Digital SecretaryThe online world has become toxicImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByJo Stevens, Shadow Digital Secretary:,  Oct | commentsWe all know that the online world has become toxic for too many of us. From abusive behaviour that causes real damage and shuts down debate to the extremism that spreads terrying ideas and incites people to commit murder. After a three year delay, the Conservatives’ promised draft Bill has finally been published but it’s weak, ineffective and won’t do the job we need it to do.As the testimony from Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen has shown, making money is all these companies care about.Facebook knew its app was damaging children’s mental health but chose to do nothing. Imaginea drugs company was selling something that made kids sick or a toy firm was selling dangerous a product, they would rightly suffer severe consequences.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  The first change we need in the Bill is to include criminal sanctions against the senior executives of the big companies for repeated breaches of the new law. We need a strong incentive to change the culture of those companies and how they operate. Without personal liability, nothing will change. And we know this works, we have it in health and safety law and in banking. Itaposs not good enough that the Conservatives left this out of their draft Bill.And it should not have taken Keir Starmer to push on this at PMQs for Boris Johnson to perform a U-turn.Another big omission from the Bill is a tough rule around legal but harmful content like racist abuse suffered by our footballers, misogyny suffered by just about any woman in public le and other abuse that makes le a misery but doesn’t hit a criminal threshold.  We need a tough duty of care on the companies which covers all that abuse because it can’t be left up to social media companies to self police it. They have already shown they can’t, or won’t do it voluntarily.After England lost the Euros final, Instagram said that monkey emojis used to attack Saka and other black players did not breach its rules. So self regulation by these companies has had its day. Finally there is a big worry that this Bill has a two tier approach to digital s putting tougher rules in place for the big “category ” sites like Facebook and Twitter but putting less stringent rules in place for the smaller sites.But as Hope Not Hate and the Anti Semitism Policy Trust and others have warned, it’s often the smaller s that host the most terrying and dangerous content with Twitter and Facebook acting as a shop window for the more extreme material. Labour believes this needs to be addressed because excluding these sites from stronger rules is playing into the hands of those who want to spread this dangerous extremism.On Wednesday, under pressure from Keir Starmer, the Prime Minister promised to bring in criminal sanctions and to bring forward the second reading of the Bill before Christmas. We will be holding him to these promises. We need our laws in place as soon as possible and for them to be effective to make all our online lives safer. Because we know from bitter experience that harms against people online can quickly move offline. story: UK and New Zealand strike trade deal which will make sauvignon blanc p cheaperBoris Johnson and Kiwi counterpart Jacinda Ardern sealed an agreement to boost trade between the two countriesThe Prime Minister is celebrating after striking a post-Brexit trade deal with New Zealand Image: Getty ImagesByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Britain and New Zealand tonight struck a trade deal which Boris Johnson claimed would slash red tape for businesses and end tarfs.The pact with the Kiwis was sealed in a video call between the Prime Minister and his counterpart Jacinda Ardern, after  months of talks. The Department for International Trade said the “groundbreaking” agreement will cut the price of New Zealand sauvignon blanc wine by p - which is its current tarf - and make Manuka honey and kiwi fruits cheaper. It will also create more chances for Britons to live and work in New Zealand - and “deeper cooperation on digital trade and climate change”, the ministry said. Get a daily morning politics briefing straight to your inbox.for the free Mirror Politics newsletter UK-New Zealand trade was worth £.billion last year and is expected to grow under the deal. However, it was unclear what the agreement means for imports of New Zealand lamb. Welsh farmers fear cheap lamb from Down Under on British supermarket shelves could hammer the UK’s sheep farming industry. Mr Johnson said: “This is a great trade deal for the United Kingdom, cementing our long friendship with New Zealand and furthering our ties with the Indo-Pacic.  “It will benefit businesses and consumers across the country, cutting costs for exporters and opening up access for our workers.” Ms Ardern said: The United Kingdom and New Zealand are great friends and close partners the historical connections that bind us run deep. “This world-leading free trade agreement lays the foundations for even stronger connections as both countries embark on a new phase in our relationship. “It is good for our economies, our businesses and our people. British business leaders hailed the agreement.  Federation of Small Businesses chairman Mike Cherry said: “New Zealand has long been a priority market for UK’s small exporters – more than a quarter of which already sell there – and we welcome efforts to build on existing trade ties that go back many decades.” Food and Drink Federation international trade chief Dominic Goudie said: “Our manufacturers will benefit from an ambitious trade deal with New Zealand that removes a range of tarfs that currently constrain exports. “Signicant growth opportunities exist as UK production becomes more competitive in the New Zealand market.” But Shadow International Trade Secretary Emily Thornberry claimed the deal would mean job losses for Britain’s farming communities, produce no extra growth and “generate just £million in additional exports for UK firms compared to pre-pandemic levels”.  She said: “As our economy recovers from the pandemic, we need trade deals that will boost jobs and growth, open up big new markets for UK exporters, and support our objectives to buy, make and sell more in Britain. “This trade deal with New Zealand fails on every count. “It is a deal whose only major winners are the mega-corporations who run New Zealand’s meat and dairy farms - all at the expense of British farmers who are already struggling to compete. “But for British jobs, growth and exports, this deal is yet another massive failure.” National Farmers’ Union President Minette Batters said the deal meant Britain “will be opening our doors to signicant extra volumes of imported food - whether or not produced to our own high standards - while securing almost nothing infor UK farmers”.  The pact involves “signicant upsides for farmers on the other side of the world who can now access our hugely valuable market but contains little discernible benefit for UK producers, either at home or overseas”, she warned. Ms Batters feared it could “damage the viability of many British farms in the years ahead, to the detriment of the public, who want more British food on their shelves, and to the detriment of our rural communities and cherished farmed landscapes”. title: 10 things you need know
story: things you need to know about COP ahead of Glasgow conferenceThe COP summit is set to take place in Glasgow between October  and November , with major figures including the Queen, Sir David Attenborough and Barack Obama set to attendSir David Attenborough is set to attend the COP conference in Glasgow Image: Getty ImagesByEve BeattieTrainee ReporterMatthew DreschReporterNada Farhoud:,  Oct | commentsWorld leaders will descend on Glasgow this month for the th United Nations Climate Change Conference. The COP summit is taking place between October  and November , with more than , delegates set to attend.Politicians are expected to thrash out deals which will help countries tackle climate change and limit global temperature changes to .C. The Queen, Sir David Attenborough, Barack Obama and Joe Biden are just a few of the major figures expected to appear at the summit. Here are the  things you need to know about COP: What is COP  COP stands for ‘conference of the parties’, the annual meeting of the countries that are members of the UN Climate Convention. These meetings have taken place since the convention was set up in Rio, Brazil, in . Since then, negotiators from most countries decide what actions need to be taken under international law to protect the climate.  COP takes place from October  – November  in Glasgow, Scotland, and is the UK’s first time playing host, in partnership with Italy. It was originally planned for November , but the pandemic forced a reschedule. The conference is opening a day earlier than planned, because of Covid-. The talks are scheduled to end at pm on Friday  November, but past experience of Cops shows they are likely to extend into the Saturday or even Sunday. Who will attend  More than , delegates from  countries will descend on Glasgow from October st, alongside some  heads of state. The world leaders, around  expected, will gather in the first few days and then depart leaving the complex negotiations to their representatives. The UK is expecting a full house from the EU - including a last hurrah for Merkel - while Biden is bringing  cabinet members and Barack Obama.  Canada, Australia, Korea, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Argentina are among others confirmed. Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping are some of the world leaders who are understood not to have confirmed their attendance in Glasgow, despite the Prime Minister calling on the country to put forward ambitious targets in a call last week. Ramaphosa and Japanaposs new PM Kishida have local elections so may miss out. North Korea Ambassador Choe Il will make the trip. Up to , climate activists, influencers and experts are also expected to show up. That includes broadcaster and natural historian Sir David Attenborough, who will address world leaders as a people’s advocate.The Queen will attend COP along with former U.S. President Barack Obama who will join current president Joe Biden. In a U-turn, so will youth climate activist Greta Thunberg. Thunberg previously refused to attend due to concerns that delegates from poorer countries would not be able to go to the event due to a lack of access to COVID- vaccines.Thousands of demonstrators are also expected.  Why is Cop important  This is the first COP since the Paris Agreement, which set out to radically decrease emissions, which will see membersto the table to state exactly what they are going to do. Adopted in , it is a landmark agreement to combat climate change unites all the worldaposs nations in a single agreement for the first time in history. The Key points were to keep global temperatures well below .Cabove pre-industrial times and endeavour to limit them even more, to .C. Also to limit the amount of greenhouse gases emitted by human activity to the same levels that trees, soil and oceans can absorb naturally, beginning at some point between  and . So far  countries and the EU have revised their actions - also known as National Determined Contributions . These have to be revisited every five years and COP marks the deadline, which has already been extended as a result of the pandemic. What is hoped to be achieved in Glasgow  It is broadly accepted there are three headline targets for COP: To keep .C in reach by ensuring all major polluters deliver new plans. To deliver a green recovery and finance package for developing countries, including the bn but also plans to fund adaptation and loss  damage. The projected harm to wildle and ecosystems increases enormously between global heating of .C and anything higher. At C, experts say there will be almost no coral reefs left, the Arctic will be ice-free in summer once a decade and huge numbers of animals and plants will be extinct. The chance of flooding will increase by %. How warm is it now  Temperatures around the world are already at about . – .C above pre-industrial levels, and greenhouse gas emissions are still on an upward trend.  Will this impact the UK Yes. A report by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change earlier this year said weather events once rare or unprecedented are becoming more common.It said that it will continue evenglobal heating is limited to .C. It also said that climate change is unequivocally being driven by human activity, which fuels these extreme weather patterns. What happensCop fails “COP was always going to be extremely tough, UK PM Boris Johnson told Bloomberg this week.The big players in the talks – the UN, the UK, the US – have already conceded that Cop will not achieve everything that was hoped for as the NDCs likely to emerge will not add up to all that is needed to ensure the world remains within .C.  That is disappointing for many observers, but is not a surprise given the complexity of the negotiations. China, India, Saudi Arabia and Turkey are the G nations yet to submit anything pre COP - although to give Ankara credit, they have finally signed up to the Paris Agreement six years after it was agreed What the UK hosts are now focused on is ensuring that there is enough progress on emissions cuts for  to “keep .C alive”, and to pursue as many other routes – phasing out coal, cutting methane and setting a path away from fossil fuels for transport etc. November Rain Tensions are rising as Cop approaches with rail workers and waste collectors going on strike, Airbnb are screwing over customers who have already booked accommodation in the city by asking for more money and Covid rates are rising.  Speaking for a planet, even the Queen piled in: “It is very irritating when they talk, but they donapost do,” she said, in a nod to national climate plansyet to land. Can I go to COP  Yes and no. In order to attend, only accredited delegates, media and politicians will have access to what is known as the Blue Zone - the area of venue managed by the UN.COPs also have a green zone, managed by the Presidency, with events for the wider public. since England’s last national lockdown officially ended and le finally started going back to normal for millions of people across the country.But with cases of Covid- rising signicantly over the last few weeks and winter on the way, there are fears that another shutdown could be on the way.In recent figures, it was revealed coronavirus infections are rising in  areas in the UK and daily cases have topped the , mark for much of the last week. With the addition of delays in the booster jab rollout, as well as immunity waning and a new Delta iant in the UK, it is feared restrictions may have to .But in the question is, what kind and when  What is the government’s plan to tackling Covid this winter   The government previously announced a Plan A and Plan B to tackle the spread of Covid- this winter, though the latter has yet to kick in. Plan A includes booster jabs for the over-s and other vulnerable groups, offering a first dose to  to -year-olds and advice to wear masks in enclosed spaces. Much of this is underway already but nevertheless infections are still rising at an alarming rate Plan A includes no additional restrictions introduced over winter, meaning there is no limit to how many people you can meet, and pubs and restaurants wonapost be closed. The government are hoping to avoid addition restricting by relying on the Covid booster jabs programme, which is being offered to around  million people, including the over s, younger adults with health conditions, and frontline health and social care workers. The NHS Test and Trace will continue, as well as the offer of free PCR test for those who have symptoms of Covid-. The government is also encouraging those who are being offered the flu jab to take it up. Brits are also being reminded to wear face coverings in crowded places, and let fresh in when meeting indoors, although this is not mandatory. According to government documents, in the event that “Plan A is not sufficient in keeping the virus at manageable levels”, Plan B will go ahead. However they have yet to make clear what the tipping point for this will be. What is Plan B   Plan B would involve theof mandatory masks, including in schools. According to the governmentaposs Autumn and Winter Plan document: If Plan B is implemented, the Government will bring back the legal requirement to wear face coverings in some settings. The precise settings will be decided at the time. In addition, schools will be handed a contingency framework for what to dovirus cases surge. This could involve theof bubbles. Mandatory vaccine passports for venues could be activated at a weekaposs notice. Under Plan B, the government would also consider asking people to work from homethey can, for a limited period”. The document states: The Government recognises this causes more disruption and has greater immediate costs to the economy and some businesses than the other Plan B interventions, so a final decision would be made based on the data at the time. Clear guidance and communications will be issued to the public and businesses, setting out the steps they should take to manage the increased risks of the virus, although itaposs not yet clear what this would involve.To find out more about Plan B, you can read our separate guide here.Will there be another lockdown this winter   Do you think Plan A will work  Let us know in the comments below. The government has said itaposs very unlikely that the nation will go into lockdown. This is due to the success of the Covid vaccination programme, which will hopefully reduce transmission and relieve pressure on the NHS. The government is hoping that by outlining Plan A and Plan B, there wonapost be a need for a national lockdown this winter. However, although ministers expect Plan B measures to be sufficient to avoid a signicant increase in infections, there is no guarantee another lockdown is off the table. Dr Quinton Fivelman, Chief Scientic Officer at London Medical Laboratory, warned thatnumbers continue to increase the government would be forced to introduce a non-existent Plan C. However, the government has insisted lockdown would be a last resort. Speaking about the Covid lockdown plan on BBC Breakfast, Mr Javid said: No one wants to see another lockdown, I certainly don’t. I don’t think we are going to need to see another lockdown. I think the vaccines are working. “But I think it would be irresponsible for any health minister in the world to say that this or that is % ruled out. “Not least because I just don’t know whether at some time in the future – next year, the year after, the year after that – there might be a vaccine escape iant that doesn’t work with the current suite of vaccines.” Comment MORE ON NHSPlan BSchoolsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: family toddler 2 kicked plane
story: Family with toddler, , kicked off plane at Heathrow because he wouldn’t wear face maskAngela Artis, , who was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, claims her family were removed from an American Airlines flight that was connecting at Heathrow as her son wouldnt keep a face mask onAngela Artis, , was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, with husband Darien and son Mason Image: instagram so_angieByTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum has claimed her family were kicked off an American Airlines flight after her two-year-old son wouldn’t keep his face mask on. Angela Artis, , was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, with husband Darien and son Mason when they were forced off the plane at Heathrow where they were making a connection. Their holiday to Santorini, in Greece, where the couple were renewing their wedding vows, turned sour on thevia Heathrow. After being removed from the American Airlines flight  last Sunday, the airline provided overnight accommodation and rebooked the Artis family onto the following day’s flight. Mrs Artis claimed it was impossible to keep a mask on a two-year-old and that there was a baby near them that wasn’t forced to wear a face covering.  She said having got on board the plane initially everything was fine with the flight crew and her son was even given a lollipop. It turned sour, she claimed, when another flight attendant came over.She told the: “But about  minutes before the flight was due to take off another attendant came over and pointed a finger at my baby. She said aposhe needs to put a mask on or he’s got to go” in a very rude way.Mrs Artis said that her heart dropped as she had no idea it was a strict policy because she claimed that she had been able to travel before without him wearing a mask. Mrs Artis added that other flight crew in the past have accepted it is not feasible to keep the mask on a two-year-old “for more than five minutes”. She said: We had tried to put it on him for the first few minutes but he just couldn’t keep it on, it’s dficult for a baby to even physically breathe with a mask on. She said that the plane then taxied back to the terminal and the family was forced to get off the plan with an announcement that it was due to a child not wearing a mask. US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Transportation Security Administration directives mean that American Airlines requires passengers aged two and older to wear face coverings at all times while indoors at airports and onboard. In a statement, the airline said: On Oct. , American Airlines flight  ed to the gate prior to departure from London Heathrow to deplane a party failing to comply with the face mask requirement. After agreeing to comply with the face mask requirement, all iniduals were rebooked for travel on the next flight to Charlotte the following day. We are reviewing this incident and a member of our team has reached out to the customers to learn more about what took place. The Mirror has contacted American Airlines for further comment. title: its both exciting soothing wild
story: It’s both exciting and soothing - the wild new hobby one woman swears byAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newWould you try lake swimming AdvertorialByEimear OHagan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct If we’ve learnt anything over the past year and a half, it’s that you never know what’s around the corner, so itaposs important to seize opportunities, push ourselves out of our comfort zone and live for the moment. KFC is doing just that by encouraging people to spice things up to mark the launch of its tasty new Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only. So to join in the fun, weaposre championing people who have challenged themselves to try new things, including Jenny Holden who has ed head first into wild swimming. The forty-seven-year-old mum of ten-year-old twins from Lichfield, Staffordshire, explains that she was in search of a new challenge, and one that would bring some excitement to her le.  ‘With my children a bit older, and less dependent on me, I found myself with a little bit more time for myself, and I wanted to use it doing something fun,’ says Jenny who runs her own PR company Chorus Communications. ‘Especially post lockdowns, with so much time spent at home, being sedentary and growing bored of my normal activities, I was craving a new hobby, and one that would really exhilarate me.’ A friend suggested Jenny try wild swimming at a quarry near her home and Jenny decided to give it a go, albeit with some nerves. ‘I’m a keen swimmer but the idea of swimming in that sort of environment was completely new to me. Also, wouldn’t it be freezing  I was intrigued enough to give it a go though, and took my first dip in August with one of my sons. ‘Plunging into the water, my first thought was – wow it’s cold! But actually, once you become acclimatised to the water temperature it feels wonderful. That first swim was really memorable, I came out of the water feeling revived and invigorated, and I knew I was a convert.’ Jenny persuaded three friends to form a wild swim gang with her and since August they have met weekly for a dip. ‘I don’t wear a wetsuit, it’s too much faff getting in and out of one, just a swimsuit and now I look forward to my swim all week. ‘Front crawling through open water, surrounded by the sounds and sights nature, it’s so amazing and it washes away the stresses of the week. It’s nothing like swimming in a pool, it’s both exciting and soothing, brilliant for body and mind. ‘It’s definitely going to get a bit nippier as we go into winter but I’m ready for the challenge!’ So in the spirit of taking the plunge and trying something new, e into a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it is only around for a limited period, available until November .Download the app, head in store or order online. story: Job advert for preschool worker praised for its hilariously honest requirementsJordan Jackson, the owner of Ladybridge Preschool in Bolton, posted a job advert telling candidates they would need to be fine leaving work each day "with unknown substances on your clothing" with colleagues Emma Taylorand Sarah McMyler" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _PAY-Kennedy-News-and-Media.jpg" width"" "" Preschool owner Jordan Jacksonwith colleagues Emma Taylorand Sarah McMyler Image: Kennedy News and MediaByLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  Oct | commentsA preschool has been praised for its ultra honest job advert setting out the daily reality of working with small children - before adding: It really is all worth it. Ladybridge Preschool, based in Bolton, posted on social media to say it was on the lookout for a new recruit who could transform themselves into a Disney princess and be able to sing out of tune in front of a crowd of tiny humans. Other requirements for the job, which involves looking after children aged two to five, includes having eyes in the back of your head and offering big, warm hugs whenever required. The viral advert reads: You must be comfortable about entering public places on your way home from work with unknown substances on your clothing.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. You must have the ability to read a story book upside down, with at least five interruptions per page. And finally, you must be prepared to engage in lots of fun activities and be prepared to get messy. Your hair and nails will be hard to maintain, but it really is all worth it! Preschool owner Jordan Jackson decided to have fun with the job description and the honest advert appears to have worked perfectly, as she says they have been inundated with hopefuls applying for the role. The -year-old said: I was surprised by the reaction online. We have been inundated with applications which is great.  The way weaposve put it out has inspired people. Itaposs inspired people to apply and Iaposd loveother nurseries would advertise in the same way. I hope it inspires them. Weaposve had so many applicants and itaposs worked. She added: I was hoping to attract someone kind-hearted with a sense of humour. You have to have that. Our staff are all like this. Theyaposre energetic, bubbly, very outgoing. We try and make the setting a home-from-home - as happy as we can. [The post] shows them through the childaposs eyes and what they see. Weaposre extremely child-led. Jordan said the childrenaposs favourite activity is finding mini beasts hidden in shaving foam, and they also have a mud kitchen and an annual paint day, meaning both pupils and staff can get really messy. The owner took inspiration for the job advert from a similar listing written by Moorland Day Nursery in Bolton, and itaposs gone down a storm online. One person replied to say: This is the best job advert ever, and a second wrote: Perfect! I wish more places made job descriptions like this. title: know women being spiked needles
story: All we know about women being spiked with needles in UK nightclubs as MPs demand actionHome Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being spiked with needles at nightclubs across the countryZara Owen believes she was spiked with an injectionByWilliam JanesDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct  Dozens of young women have come forward to recall their terror in finding a prick in their arm or leg realising they had been spiked by injection in nightclubs.Several said they were avoiding clubs and house parties as a result - or were wearing thick denim to protect themselves. Police chiefs said plain clothes officers were likely to be deployed in nightclubs although womensapos groups warned some women struggled to trust forces in the wake of Sarah Everardaposs murderer.Home Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being injected at nightclubs across the country.Universities have said they are working with bars and police to help ensure studentsapos safety after the reports.Have you been affected by this story  Get in touch at webnews@mirror Campaigners call for changes to make night venues safer Groups from more than  universities around the UK have joined an online campaign calling for the boycott of nightclubs. Campaigners say they are seeking tangible changes to make night-time venues safer, such as covers stoppers for drinks, better training for staff and more rigorous searches of clubbers. A petition to make it a legal requirement for nightclubs to thoroughly search guests on entry, started last week, has already gained more than , signatures. The National Union of Students issue statement Larissa Kennedy, president of the National Union of Students , said: Itaposs absolutely disgusting that in the past few days a number of students have reported instances of women being spiked on nights out. My rage, love and solidarity goes out to all those who have been impacted by these violent acts, and all other women and marginalised folks who experience sexual violence on our campuses and in our communities. One studentaposs story A student has told how she believes she was spiked with an injection during a night out with friends as police say reports of spiking are on the rise.Zara Owen, , from Surrey, who is a student at the University of Nottingham, said she went for a night out with friends last Monday but then blacked out soon after arriving at a venue.Speaking to BBC Breakfast, she said: I went out with my friends to a nightclub in the city - nothing more than what we would usually do. I remember going to the bar, going to the toilet, going to the photobooth, and then after that moment my memory is a blank until I get home and Iaposm getting my phone charger. I know I didnapost drink as much as I usually would on a night out this night, and the fact that I donapost remember anything is terrying for me because this is something that is a very rare occasion to me.  Iaposve never suffered with memory loss and then the next morning, obviously I did with the memory loss, I woke up with a really painful leg. I found a pin prick in my leg which was the epicentre of all pain. It made me unable to walk and I was limping around. As a young person whoaposs at university, Iaposm hearing stories of people who have been to nightclubs and they have been injected. I have heard stories of someone having it through their hand or through their back so this kind of gave me an idea this had happened to me. Ms Owen added she was afraid that she may have contracted a diseasea dirty needle had been used. What did the university say  A University of Nottingham spokesperson said: We are extremely concerned by these reports - no-one should feel unsafe on a night out. We are working closely with Nottinghamshire Police and the cityaposs nightle venues to monitor, review and learn from incidents and experiences in the city centre. We have contacted them about the specic concerns raised and will continue to liaise with them to actively tackle societal problems and challenge behaviours.The NHS website provides some guidelines on what to doyour skin has been punctured with a used needle. They advise to aposwash the wound using running water and plenty of soapapos, aposdry the wound and cover it with a waterproof plaster or dressingapos and to not scrub the wound or suck any blood. Nottingham Policeaposs websites has some guidance on what to doyour drink has been spiked, but they currently do not have any guidelines on being injected. They advise to: Tell the people you’re with and make sure you’re someone where you feel safe. Alert a member of staff at the pub or club you are at. If you feel unwell you should seek medical attention immediately and tell them that you believe your drink has been spiked.Police in Nottinghamshire investigateNottinghamshire Police has seen a rising number of reports of spiking over recent months and are now stepping up operations to tackle the problem. Superintendent Kathryn Craner said: Over the last few months we have seen an increase in reports where people believe that drugs may have been put in their drink - thataposs due to the fact that they have experienced a distinctly dferent feeling to their normal reaction to alcohol. But weaposve also received a small number of reports where people are telling us, as Zara has, that this has been associated with a pain or a mark on a part of their body, scratching sensation, and as though they have been physically spiked. The force has arrested a man as part of the wider operation to tackle spiking in Nottingham. Police Scotland also investigate reports Police are investigating reports of people being spiked by injection in the Edinburgh, Dundee, Glasgow and Aberdeen areas. It follows reports on social media about people being targeted inside venues in Scotland. Police Scotland said a small number of reports from the four areas are being investigated but do not appear to be linked. The force has also received a report of a drink-spiking incident at a venue in the Stirling area and inquiries are ongoing. A Police Scotland spokesman said: We are aware of posts circulating on social media about spiking incidents involving injections in Scotland. Officers are carrying out inquiries, and a small number of reports from the Edinburgh, Dundee, Glasgow and Aberdeen areas are being investigated. These do not appear to be linked. We take all reports seriously and we would encourage anyone who believes they have been a victim of spiking in any form to contact police via .  What politicians are saying about the issue“ These are obviously vile crimes,” said Commons Home Affairs Select Committee chairwoman Yvette Cooper.Ms Cooper, a former Shadow Home Secretary, said she received a report today from a victim who attended a hospital casualty unit last night “as a result of a possible injection spiking”. The victim “referred to there being three other people who were in the AE at the same time for spiking more widely, who were unable to walk as a result of drink spiking”.Home Secretary Priti Patel has requested an urgent update from police following harrowing reports of women being injected at nightclubs across the country.A Home Office source said: Weaposve asked the police to look into whataposs going on. We need to understand the scale of the problem. The thought of whataposs going on is just horrendous. What are the experts saying about it Some experts have cast doubt the use of needle spiking being a widespread phenomenon due to multiple iables such as the size of needle needed, the amount of liquid to cause an effect as well as the medical know-how needed to perform the injection.Guy Jones, senior scientist at drugs charity the Loop, told VICE World News: “GHB would be a poor candidate for injection due to the large amount of fluid needed, and therefore the thick, painful needle. This means that the substance involved would be something that would be highly detectable for several days in a toxicology screening such as a benzodiazepine.”David Caldicott, an emergency medicine consultant and founder of drug testing project WEDINOS, also said: “There are a couple of things that are disconcerting about this story. The technical and medical knowledge required to perform this would make this deeply improbable. It is at the level of a state-sponsored actor incapacitating a dissident, like the Novichok incident. The idea that a clubber would do this to a fellow clubber seems highly unlikely to me. title: most broken shelter dog finally
story: Most broken shelter dog finally accepts treat from volunteers after  daysBetty the shelter dog finally decided she was brave enough to approach a handler offering a treat on the st day of her stay at DogsRescue in WorsleyThe dog finally accepted a tasty treat after  days Image: DogsRescueByFiona Callow:,  Oct | comments A dog described as the most broken a shelter has ever seen finally took a treat from a volunteer’s hand for the first time in  days. Betty finally decided she was brave enough to approach a handler offering a tasty treat on the st day of her stay at DogsRescue in Worsley. Bettyaposs transformation was slow but incredible, and the sweet moment was captured on video, the Manchester Evening News reports.The shelter wrote in a video caption: “Betty taking a treat from our hands. This moment has been  days in the making. “Probably the most broken rehab dog we have taken, her transformation whilst slow is incredible.  Moments like this are golden. We are so proud of you Betty.” Later that day they shared the full video, and said: “Betty taking a treat. She’s sat and watched other dogs do this thousands of times. Love, kindness, time and patience pay off in the end. “This was on her st day at our rescue. All in your own time, beautul girl. There’s no clock ticking on how long you can stay here.” In the video, the handler stays calm and still, offering out the treat while Betty is seen looking around tentatively, starting to approach several times, before doubling back, taking a few steps backwards, and then starting again. She then seemingly surveys the area to make sure that the coast is clear before walking up steadily towards the handler, finally taking the treat very gently before beating a hasty retreat. The tweet has gained more than , likes and nearly  comments, with users praising the rescue for allowing Betty to overcome her fears at her own pace. DogsRescue was founded by Emma in  with the aim to rehabilitate dogs across Europe and the UK to homes in the Manchester area. They pride themselves on being a kennel free environment, and believe in ‘pack rehabilitation’, allowing the dogs to enjoy a lestyle where they can exercise and socialise with the other animals, gaining confidence from each other, before eventually being rehomed.  One user said: “That is so beautul to see but I can’t help thinking what the beautul baby has been through to be so frightened. “Thank you so much for your patience and perseverance. You guys are truly amazing.” Another commented: “Bless her, so thankful to you for giving her the opportunity to express herself at her own pace without the time pressure of finding a home. “Thank you for the wonderful work you do.” A third said: “Breaks my heart to see her check her escape route first. Thank goodness she has you guys.”In a further post on Twitter, the rescue said: “Betty is a smart, sweet dog who was unbelievably afraid. It was unthinkable to us to end the le of a healthy dog just because they need time and patience.“It’s a privilege to be on this confidence building journey with her and watch her blossom into a happy member of our pack.” Comment MORE ON FitnessAnimalsDogs" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news new-covid-delta-plus-iant-"Coronavirus new cases and deaths on October ByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments The new strain of the Delta Covid iant could be even more transmissible, experts have warned.The so-called Delta Plus, also known as AY. will not effect current plans to tackle the spread of Covid during winter, despite fears the NHS could be overwhelmed by hospital submissions due to respiratory illnesses. Previous iants of the coronavirus have wreaked havoc as they can spike infection rates across the country.Health experts from the NHS are now encouraging the government to enact its contingency plan for further restrictions, which may include another lockdown. Business secretary Kwasi Kwarteng said in response: This time last year we didnapost have the vaccine. We donapost want to go back into lockdown and further restrictions. A spokesperson for Prime Minister Boris Johnson added: As you know it’s something we’re keeping a very close eye on because of the strength of our genomic capability we are able to keep a very close watch on any iants that are emerging.What is the new Delta plus Covid iant  The new coronavirus iant, known as AY.., is an offshoot of the Delta strain, which is dominant across the world.Viruses mutate and change to fight against the antibodies that learn to kill them. It means immunity to viruses are often hard to keep up with. Some virus iants are more easily spread and can be more infectious. Some strains are also known to be more severe. Is the New Delta strain more transmissible  It is currently unclearthe new iant is indeed more severe or infectious. Tests are currently underway in an attempt to determine this. However, according to Dr Jeffrey Barrett, the director of the Covid- Genomics Initiative at the Wellcome Sanger Institute in Cambridge, and Prof Francois Balloux, the director of the University College London Genetics Institute, AY.. could be -% more transmissible than the original iant. He told the Financial Times: Its potential higher transmissibility could at this stage only explain a tiny fraction of additional cases. “It’s around % frequency [now], and assuming it may be % more transmissible, that would only explain an additional % extra infections [every five or so days].  However, the PMaposs spokesperson said: Thereaposs no evidence to suggest this iant, which I think is the AY. you are referring to, is more easily spread. There’s no evidence for that but as you would expect we’re monitoring it closely and won’t hesitate to take actionnecessary.” Thereaposs no evidence provided to us that we have seen that suggests it is more easily spread. Will the Covid vaccine still work  Experts say at this early stage, it is unlikely the new iant will escape the current vaccines. Tests are currently under way to establish how big of a threat this new iant poses. The Covid- Genomics UK Consortium , which tracks new iants, said the new iant “is likely to become dominant” in Britainit is found to be more infectious. However, it said there is no evidence to support this yet. More recently experts have argued there is a case for a Delta-specic vaccine, according to The Independent. story: Pub landlord left frustrated after group refuses to pay for meal after eating itThe Pack Horse, in the Peak District village of Hayfield, was visited by a group who left without paying despite staff checking on them when they first got their foodThe Pack Horse, which is in the Peak District village of Hayfield, is one of the North Wests leading and most respected gastropubsByDaisy JacksonAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA pub landlord has shamed a group of customers for refusing to pay for a meal they had already eaten. The Pack Horse, which is in the Peak District village of Hayfield, was visited by a group who didnapost complain when staff came and checked on them after they got their food. Staff say that the group chose to complain once theyaposd eaten most of the meal.The group allegedly tried to ask for a new dish, which was refused, and eventually left without paying the bill, Manchester Evening News reports. Owner and chef Luke Payne said that one member of the group then had the nerve to wink at him as they left. Were the diners right to leave  Have your say in the comments  The pub takes card details at the time of booking in case of no-shows or walk-outs, but the group reportedly said they would cancel their cards. Luke said the ordeal was immensely frustrating for him and his staff. He said: They were perfectly pleasant to begin with and then everything just changed. After theyaposd eaten about  per cent of the food, a lady brought her plate up to the bar and said it wasnapost to her liking, wasnapost what she expected, and could she swap to another meal for free   To which I said aposNoapos, because sheaposd eaten most of it and we canapost give food away for free when itaposs just personal preference. Thataposs not really how it works. Luke said his small team had already checked in with the group of customers and there were no complaints made about their food. When the group threatened to not pay their bill, Luke said he told them: aposThataposs not really acceptable, youaposve eaten most it, and you were given the opportunity to say there was something wrong with it.apos  He added: If theyaposd flagged it up in the check-back we could have done something to recty it. We donapost actively like making people unhappy, itaposs our job for people to have a really good night. We love people leaving with a buzz and knowing theyaposve had a great time with us, and  per cent of the people we have in are absolutely lovely and have a great time. We put in so much effort and passion and love, so every negative comment is taken personally. We will always do our utmost to fix a problemsomething is wrong -weaposve made a mistake weaposll hold our hands up and weaposll own it. So in an instance where absolutely nothing is wrong and people have kicked off, it hurts. The Pack Horse is one of the North Westaposs leading and most respected gastropubs, earning itself a place in the Estrella Dam Gastropubs list. Luke says that business has been great since they were able to reopen their doors after lockdown, but he says the post-pandemic kindness is fading. He said: I feel like there was a point in the pandemic where everyone was like aposBe kind, be nice. But Iaposve certainly noticed over the last couple of weeks that thereaposs been more stressed-out people with shorter tempers, and I know that thereaposs a lot of hard times for people at the moment, but it doesnapost take much to be nice to others. story: Queen showing slight cold signs but spotted driving Land Rover and walking dogsHer Majesty, , felt “a little tired” on Tuesday evening, before royal doctors were called to her living quarters at Windsor Castle, it is understoodHer Majesty, , felt “a little tired” on Tuesday evening, before royal doctors were called to her living quarters at Windsor Castle, it is understood Image: Getty ImagesByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Oct | comments The Queen has been ordered to put her health first after being forced to cancel a planned trip to Northern Ireland due to ill health. The -year-old monarch was feeling “a little tired” on Tuesday evening, before royal doctors were called to her living quarters at Windsor Castle, it is understood. Upon waking on Wednesday morning, ahead of a planned departure from her Berkshire home at midday to travel to Belfast, the steely Queen was said to be “showing slight signs of a seasonal cold”.Her Majesty, who has had a jam packed schedule of engagements since ing from her summer break at Balmoral, took covid test which confirmed she was not suffering from coronavirus. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up But palace medics advised her to take a period of “immediate rest” for the next few days. The nation’s longest reigning monarch is resting at Windsor Castle but will still receive her ministerial red boxes which she will attend to. She is still expected at this stage to host a reception in Glasgow on November  for the Cop climate change conference. Several engagements in her diary for next week remain as yet unchanged, but courtiers said they would maintain a “cautious view” with any plans. The Queen was set to attend a series of engagements at Hillsborough Castle on Wednesday and Thursday attend a service in St Patrick’s Church, Armagh to commemorate the centenary of the foundation of Northern Ireland. A Buckingham Palace spokesman said: “The Queen has reluctantly accepted medical advice to rest for the next few days.  “Her Majesty is in good spirits and is disappointed that she will no longer be able to visit Northern Ireland, where she had been due to undertake a series of engagements today and tomorrow. “The Queen sends her warmest good wishes to the people of Northern Ireland, and looks forward to visiting in the future.” It emerged this week that the Queen turned down the ‘Oldie of the Year’ trophy because she feels she does not meet the criteria, believing “you are only as old as you feel”. Despite her period of rest to take it easy, the Queen was spotted on Wednesday driving around the Windsor estate and enjoying taking her dogs for a walk. A royal source said: “The Queen’s enthusiasm for ing to a fully packed schedule of engagements following the coronavirus restrictions being lted has been incredibly admirable. “There is certainly no cause for alarm.  “Her Majesty doesn’t know any other pace than full on and used to being incredibly busy, especially of late, but perhaps it is in her best interests that she takes this time to rest and recuperate before she starts once again.” Courtiers believe the cancellation of the Queen’s trip will serve as a reminder that the head of state - at the age of  - cannot do what was expected of her  or  years ago. In recent weeks she has for the first time been seen walking with a stick at public engagements. Joe Little, managing editor of Majesty magazine, said the Queen’s autumn schedule had been more crammed than expected, but last-minute cancellations were inevitable in the future. Since the Queen ed from Balmoral Castle at the start of October, she has met Canadian troops at Windsor, launched the Queen’s Baton Relay for the Commonwealth Games, attended the Royal British Legion centenary service at Westminster Abbey, travelled to Cardf for the Welsh Senedd opening, and hosted a global investment summit reception, as well as holding audiences and video calls.  Mr Little said: “I think when you get to the age of  and you have a role such as the Queen has, there is an inevitability about last-minute cancellations. “Unfortunately, I think this is just how it’s going to have to be from time to time. “The fact that she has been busy and seemingly healthy and happy of late shows that clearly looks can be deceptive unless something has happened overnight.” He added: “Mentally, the Queen is pin sharp as ever and when she makes speeches she speaks well. “But you notice that the body is perhaps a little bit less so. “Every now and again there will be this reminder that she is  and she can’t do what was expected of her ,  years ago.  Just five years away from her th birthday and next year due to celebrate her Platinum Jubilee -  years on the throne, the nation’s longest reigning monarch still keeps a busy diary of events and audiences and deals with her daily red boxes of official papers. She held two audiences on Tuesday via video link from Windsor Castle, greeting the Japanese ambassador Hajime Hayashi and the EU ambassador Joao de Almeida, followed by a reception for business leaders including Microsoft founder Bill Gates in the evening. At the weekend, she enjoyed a day at the races at Ascot, and on Monday held a virtual audience with the new Governor-General of New Zealand. Royal sources said the Queen’s “enthusiasm to get on with the job” has shown now sign of letting up, but most conceded she would be advised to “take her foot off the gas” to maintain her health. It was revealed last week that Her Majesty had taken the “personal decision” to give up regular drinking by her doctors as she keeps up a busy schedule ahead of her Platinum Jubilee celebrations.  Due to her age the Queen is expected to have had her Covid booster jab, following her first inoculation in January.At the time she broke with protocol to announce she had been given her first injection, alongside husband Prince Philip, from a royal doctor at Windsor Castle.The head of state made the personal decision to let it be known she had accepted the vaccine to send a “message of hope” to the country, as Britain reaches a crisis point in the battle against coronavirus. story: Queen urged to step to one side after she was told by doctors to restThe -year-old monarch cancelled her trip to Northern Ireland after her doctor advised her to take a few days off and rest after a hectic few weeksThe Queen was told to take a few days of rest after a busy few weeks of travelling and hosting events Image: Getty ImagesByShiler Mahmoudi:,  Oct | commentsThe Queen should step to one side after being told to rest by doctors, a royal source has claimed. Her Majesty, , was forced to cancel her two-day trip to Northern Ireland after being advised take some time out of her schedule. She pulled out of the trip just five hours before she was due to arrive. Buckingham Palace said in a statement: “The Queen has reluctantly accepted medical advice to rest for the next few days. “Her Majesty is in good spirits and is disappointed that she will no longer be able to visit Northern Ireland, where she had been due to undertake a series of engagements today and tomorrow. “The Queen sends her warmest good wishes to the people of Northern Ireland, and looks forward to visiting in the future.” The Northern Ireland trip was cancelled so last minute palace staff were already waiting in Belfast, the Mail Online reports.  A royal source said of the Queen: With her Platinum Jubilee on the horizon, many are thinking that perhaps her private office needs to look at the diary again. Another source added: No one is saying that she should take a step back, but perhaps another slight step to one side might be in order.  It has been confirmed that the monarch is not sick due to Covid-, and that she simply needed to rest after a busy schedule and weeks of travelling. This week the Queen welcomed guests following Boris Johnsonaposs investment summit. She met with business leaders, tech entrepreneurs and politicians, including the the Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates. The monarch also recently ed from a summer in Balmoral, and opened the Welsh Senedd last week. Over the weekend, she had attended the Ascot races and on Monday met with new governor-general of New Zealand virtually.Also last week, the Queen had attended a service at Westminster Abbey for the Royal British Legion, where she was spotted with a walking stick for the first time. The Palace has insisted that there is nothing to be concerned about and that her doctor instructed her to rest.  The Northern Ireland trip would have seen the Queen attend a service marking the centenary of the partition of Ireland and the formation of Northern Ireland. She was also due to visit Hillsborough Castle, which was renamed to the Royal Hillsborough Castle, and would have met with some pandemic heroes. This is not the first time the Queen has been forced to cancel a trip. In January of last year, she was due to visit the Womenaposs Institutebranch in Sandringham, Norfolk but did not attend due to ill health. She was also forced to cancel her appearance at an event at St Pauls in London in June  because she was feeling ill. story: Man arrested after young woman injected with needle in nightclubThe victim was rushed to AE and spent the night in hospital after the terrying incident, which happened last Tuesday in Nottingham. A man has been arrestedEllie SImpson, whose sister was targeted in a Nottingham nightclubByCallum Parke:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct A man has been arrested days after a young woman was allegedly injected with a needle in a nightclub. The victim was rushed to AE and spent the night in hospital after the terrying incident, which allegedly happened last Tuesday in Nottingham. Ellie Simpson, the womanaposs sister, said her sibling was with friends in Stealth nightclub when she felt a pinching or scratching sensation on the back of her arm. She began to feel ill, and was taken to AE, where she spent the night on a drip.Ellie told Derbyshire Live that her sister, who studies in Nottingham but is from Derby, has been left seriously shaken by the experience. She said: Sheaposs OK now, but sheaposs still really shaken up and afraid to go out. She went out for a night out and had only had a couple of drinks, so had drank less than she would normally. They were trying to leave the club and on the way out she felt something on the back of her arm, a pinching or scratching sensation, and she canapost remember anything after that. The police took urine samples so I donapost knowthey will be able to find anything. I felt sick, because you see these things happen to other people. You never expect to have it happen to anybody that you know. And then I obviously felt angry, and you just question why, why does somebody want to do that  What were their intentions  Iaposm just thankful she was with a friend becauseshe wasnapost, what would have happened  Spiking is the act of adding alcohol or a drug to food or drink without the knowledge of the person who consumes it. Reports of spikings have been re across the country in recent weeks, with particular concern about the use of needles given the risk of infection with HIV.It is recommended by the NHS that anyone concerned about contracting HIV should use soap to clean the wound, and buy anti-HIV medication within  hours of the incident.Signs that a drink may have been tampered with include a foggy appearance, excessive bubbles, sinking ice or a change in colour. If someone has been spiked, it is recommended to tell a member of staff and to ensure someone stays with the victim, calling an ambulancetheir condition deteriorates. It is important to ensure they do not travel on their own, or drink more alcohol. But Ellie, who has herself been spiked while studying in Loughborough, says women can only do so much to protect themselves and that more should be done to create a safe environment for everyone. She said: Ever since that [Ellie being spiked], my sister has been a lot more conscious in terms of putting your hands over your drink. But when itaposs a needle, how do you stop that  You canapost. Unless you go out in a suit of armour, which weaposre not going to do. Evenyou do search people, itaposs like looking for a needle in a haystack. I personally I donapost know how youaposd go about stopping it, as metal detectors may not pick needles up as theyaposre so small. As women, we shouldnapost have to go out on a night out, thinking have I got my bag, have I got my keys, then thinking, am I safe to go out, am I going to get spiked tonight  It shouldnapost be like that. Boycotts of nightclubs across the country have been organised over the next fortnight in protest. Using the name aposGirls Nights Inapos, events are happening in Derby and Nottingham on Wednesday, October , to coincide with Wednesday nights often being busy student nights, with similar happening across the country into early November. But Ellie has said that anyone, including men, are welcome and encouraged to become part of the campaign for greater awareness and protection in clubs. To other men it must seem like we are blaming them, even though we know it is not all men. I suppose in a club environment, the only sort of way I would feel safe isyou could see a manaposs hands and know where they are, but how you do that  And you shouldnapost have to do that. But weaposre keen to say itaposs not all men. Nottinghamshire police have said that a -year-old man has been arrested after receiving reports of a number of incidents in recent days. He has since been released on bail. He was arrested on suspicion of possession of class A and class B drugs and cause to administer poison or noxious thing with intent to injure, aggrieve and annoy following an incident in Lower Parliament Street on October , four days after Ellieaposs sister was spiked.A petition for greater security checks for nightclubs has also reached over , signatures, surpassing the threshold needed for the matter to be debated in Parliament. story: UK weather: Flooding hits UK as cars abandoned and mini tornado wreaks havocStorm Aurore made its way across from France last night, bringing mph winds and several centimetres of rain that hit London, Essex, Sussex and Kent particularly badly overnight Image: Stephen Huntley HVCByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsMotorists had to be evacuated from their cars after lashing rains caused parts of England to flood overnight. An elderly man was photographed being led from his stranded vehicle which got stuck in a foot of water in Southend, Essex. The town had already endured a miserable day of weather on Wednesday, with overwhelmed drains pumping raw sewage out onto the sea front. Across the county more than  people had called the fire service for emergency help with flood related incidents before .am. Have you been impacted by the flooding  Email webnews@mirror  In Sussex the M was shut between junction  and  following a serious crash, leaving emergency services needing to clear water and debris. Earlier on Wednesday a suspected mini tornado caused havoc in Widnes, Cheshire with garden walls, bins and ornaments flung onto the main road. Late last night residents of Ferring in West Sussex took to social media to claim they have also been struck by a tornado. One person said: I’m in Ferring, I was in my daughter’s room at the time and we heard a bang and the windows shook and both wondered what on earth has happened.  Locals shared photos of damage to their gardens, including a smashed brick wall and toppled furniture. Four people had to be rescued from the roof of their car after it became swamped.  They were left balancing on the top of the vehicle that was stuck in four feet of fast flowing water at St Kew, Cornwall.Police were first on the scene just before .pm and then called in Cornwall Fire and Rescue Service.Crews from Wadebridge and Delabole were sent along with water rescue units from St Austell and Bude, supported by an Area manager and group manager.  Londoners complained of “terrying” journeys home on Wednesday night. One person tweeted: “The rain tonight coming back from London was the worst I’ve seen in a long time. Loads of deep flooding from Hammersmith through to the M.” Another wrote: “Terrying drive home from West London to Rochester, Medway. Torrential rain all the way with flooding and stranded vehicles along the route. Still raining...”  People across the south of the country woke up to tumultuous scenes of flooding this morning after a storm moving in from France brought with it strong winds and heavy rains. Storm Aurore was expected to dump mm of rain and blow mph winds in the worst affected areas. The Met Office issued a yellow rain warning covering most of southern England for Wednesday night and into Thursday, meaning people living there could see transport delays, flooding and power issues. The Met Office issued yellow rain warnings for the southern counties and Channel Islands until am on Thursday, but said the most severe impact of the storm would be over northern France.  It added the unsettled weather was likely to continue for the rest of the week, with showers and breezy conditions across western Scotland and some areas of central and northern England and Wales on Friday. Forecasters predict there to be more persistent rain over the weekend, with the heaviest rain expected in western Scotland, where -mm could fall in  hours. Northern Ireland, northern England and Wales, could see up to mm of rain, while southern and central areas will see light rain. story: Two men caught with almost £k of drug money in supermarket bags for le jailedPero Mitrovic, , was jailed on October  for  months and Milan Kosoric, , was sentenced to a total of four years and three months imprisonmentPero Mitrovic was jailed for  months Image: Kent Police   SWNS.COMByJulia RobertsChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsTwo men have been jailed after being found with almost £, of drug money stashed in supermarket bags for le. A court heard the plastic-wrapped bundles of notes were found in several shopping bags during a police raid at the home of Pero Mitrovic in Kensington, London, where he rented out a room to Milan Kosoric. Officers also found just over g of cocaine and drugs paraphernalia at the property and in a parked car outside. Prosecutor Tim Hunter told Maidstone Crown Court that the amount of cash found plainly doesnapost equate to the small quantity of the class A drug which had been ided into  deals. Both men, who have no previous convictions in the UK or their native country, admitted possessing criminal property in respect of the cash on a jointly owned basis.  Mitrovic, , was jailed on October  for  months and -year-old Kosoric, who also pleaded guilty to possessing cocaine with intent to supply, was sentenced to a total of four years and three monthsapos imprisonment. The flat in Redclfe Street was raided on March  this year and the cash totalling £, was found in Kosoricaposs rear bedroom. Mr Hunter said: The cash was bundled up and marked into separate amounts and kept in a iety of robust supermarket shopping aposbags for leapos. Police also found six bags containing the vast majority of drug deal bags, a sealing machine and money counter. A further  cocaine wraps were found in a VW car. Craig Rush, defending Kosoric, said he had been entrusted by those further up the chain to act as a storekeeper for the drugs and money. Tony Wyatt, defending Mitrovic, told the court he knew the money was related to crime but not that it came from drug trafficking.He added: He could and should have put a stop to what was happening and ask his co-defendant to leave the flat. However, Judge Charles Gratwicke said it beggared belief that on seeing the money and paraphernalia he would not have known what was going on. Passing sentence, he told Mitrovic: You clearly must have been aware of the criminal activity that was going on, you clearly were permitting that criminal activity to take place, and there is little doubt that there was to be some personal gain.  Jailing Kosoric, Judge Gratwicke added he had played an active role in the illicit operation. Class A drugs bring with them nothing but misery, degradation and occasionally death to those who become addicted, he said. Those who prey upon the addiction class A drugs bring can expect to receive immediate prison sentences to reflect societyaposs abhorrence of the evil trade and to deter others. Detective Superintendent Lee Morton of Kent Police who investigated the case, said: Kosoric and Mitrovic both occupied key roles in an organised criminal network, and whilst both of them may not have directly orchestrated the drug supply chains running into Kent, they had clearly been entrusted to look after and redistribute vast sums of criminal cash. Both men have now rightly been jailed and the fact that we have been able to successfully and permanently seize all the money is equally important. Some of the work we do can take months of painstaking investigation but it is important that people see that we wonapost allow criminals to benefit from their illegal activity. Any ill-gotten cash will be taken from them and where possible redistributed to our local communities for everyoneaposs benefit. story: Which type of cough is Covid  How to tell the dference between virus and a coldAs the worst cold ever sweeps the country, its natural for people to wondertheyre simply under the weather from a severe cold or been infected with Covid. Heres the full breakdown to help you tell the dferenceConcerns over Covid symptoms have risen as the worst cold ever sweeps the nation Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByMalvika Padin:,  Oct | comments After nearly two years of Covid safety measures, such as staying at home, social distancing, sanitizing and wearing face coverings, many people are being struck down by whataposs been dubbed the worst lurgy ever.Having had limited exposure to ailments like colds over the last  months, our immune systems have become more susceptible to common colds, especially now that restrictions have lted. Soyouaposre suffering with a cold-like ailment and youaposre worried you have Covid, hereaposs everything you need to know - including symptoms and safety measures.What are the symptoms of a cold  Symptoms of the recent cold sweeping the UK appear to include :A sore or scratchy throat Losing your voice Body aches and continuous headaches Frequent sneezing A runny nose A continuous cough A change in smell or taste A fever or temperature from  degrees Celsius and above What is a Covid cough  According to a February  joint report from WHO-China, a dry cough is the second most common symptom of Covid-, with % people reporting it. A dry cough means youaposre coughing without phlegm, and in Covid sufferers, this cough is often very deep and low from the bottom of the lungs, according to medical experts. However, having a dry cough doesnapost necessarily mean you have Covid, as it can also be caused by allergies, being exposed to dry air, smoking and other health conditions like asthma and GERD.How can you tell the dference between a cold and Covid  The simple truth is you canapost really the dference based on the symptoms alone, because several symptoms are also experienced by those with Covid-. Experts have said that itaposs tough to tell the dference, especially for those who have taken two doses of the Covid jab.They have warned against self-diagnosis, recommending testing as the only sure way to know. If you have a continuous cough, fever or changes in sense of smell taste, the best thing to do is take a PCR or lateral flow test and stay at home until full recovery from symptoms, eventhe first few tests come back negative. Anyone suffering from respiratory symptoms is also advised to seek medical helptheir health worsens and symptoms such as shortness of breath, blue lips, chest pain, or coughing blood appear.How to reco ver q uic kly If multiple Covid tests have come back negative, it can be safe to assume youaposre suffering from a simple cold. The best way to recover from any common cold, no matter how severe, is drinking plenty of fluids, like hot water with honey and lemon for sore throats, using over-the-counter medication for aches and pains and resting as much possible. And though restrictions have lted, it is recommended that we ease back into socialising and partying until our immune systems are able to fend off these pesky colds. title: woman left without water flat
story: Woman left without water in flat for five days says living conditions are nightmareAnna Gronowska said her block of flats in Trafford, Greater Manchester, has been experiencing issues since Friday. She has spoken of her concerns as the issue has not been fixed yetAnna Gronowska has been without water at her flat since Friday Image: MEN MediaByAdam MaidmentChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsA -year-old woman who has been left with no running water for five days has described her living conditions as a nightmare. Anna Gronowska said her block of flats in Trafford, Greater Manchester, has been experiencing issues since Friday.The woman said she found out the shared pump room on the ground floor of the building had water gushing out of it like a waterfall, so she contacted the local utilities company, the Manchester Evening News reports.However, she was told that the pipes in the area were operating fine and that it could be an isolated incident relating to her building. Anna then contacted Portland Block Management, who runs the building, and informed them of the problems at The Park apartments in Chester Road.  She said: We’ve been living without water since Friday. It could be dangerous and it is a real worry that something worse could happen soon. This isn’t just a simple leak, it’s a waterfall that’s just flowing out everywhere - itaposs a nightmare. Anna said the management company told her they had tried to fix the issues several times but contractors needed to be called out. She added: I could understandit took  or  hours to fix but itaposs now five days and we still donapost have water. There are vulnerable and older people living in the building and I’m concerned that the flats nearest the water pipe could get water damageit’s not sorted soon.  The management company said the complex problem had been caused by a fracture in the main water pipes. Equipment in the building’s pump room had also been accidentally damaged. A spokesperson for Portland Block told the M.E.N.: This is an extremely complex job to remedy and has involved multiple contractors and repeated visits. We have kept a timeline of all responses and ongoing work from the point the matter occurred. We have provided water during this period and have advised residents that we will continue to do so until the matter is resolved. We have kept in contact with residents by phone, email and have also hand delivered letters to each apartment. We are hopeful the matter will be brought to a close by tomorrow . The Mirror has contacted Portland Block Management for an update on the repair work, but has not heard back from the company yet. title: boat captain finds huge tooth
story: Boat captain finds huge tooth that belonged to prehistoric Megalodon sharkWhile Michael has found many other shark teeth in the past, he said he would be keeping this one due to how impressive it was.Michael Nastasio found the - -inch megalodon tooth just off the coast of Venice, Florida Image: @michael.nastasio NewsflashByLee Bullen:,  Oct | commentsA boat captain is in awe after finding a huge tooth that belonged to a prehistoric shark once considered to have been one of the biggest predators on the planet. Megalodons, meaning aposbig toothapos, are a now-extinct shark species that once swam in the Earthaposs waters. They are believed to have lived from about  to . million years ago, from the Early Miocene to the Pliocene eras. Captain Michael Nastasio, from the city of Venice in Sarasota County, found the    inchestooth just off the coast of his home city, while on a shark-tooth chartering trip with his company: Black Gold Fossil Charters. The area is noted for the shark teeth found on the local sea bed. While Michael has found many other shark teeth in the past, he said he would be keeping this one due to how impressive it was.  He said: I have been fossil hunting for almost  years, and running my own charter now for a little over a year. I have found thousands of Megalodon shark teeth and other ious fossils.” After the discovery last week, Michael said he was in awe of the huge fossil. I canapost take my eyes off of it, he said. Megalodons were previously classied as part of the Lamnidae family, which would have meant that they were closely related to great white sharks . However, they are now listed as part of the Otodontidae family, which is extinct. Megalodons are often considered to have been one of the biggest predators on the planet. Michael said his job means he is in the water with the customers a lot. “You can hear them underwater when they find a tooth,” he said. “You can hear them yell... It just makes you feel good. In , the American-Chinese sci-fi film aposThe Megapos was released starring British actor Jason Statham, that was based on a group of scientists encountering a -foot-long Megalodon shark while on a rescue mission at the bottom of the Pacic Ocean. Markle says she and Prince Harry were overjoyed and “overwhelmed” following the birth of their daughter Lilibet.The Duchess of Sussex, , offered a brief and rare glimpse into the familyaposs lives in a letter to members of the United States Congress and Senate calling for paid leave for new parents. The duchess, who is mother to UK-born Archie and US-born Lilibet, said paid leave should be “a national right” as she reflected on how hard her parents worked and how she herself started working at the age of .  Meghan reflected on her family le after the birth of Lilibet earlier this year, saying: “In June, my husband and I welcomed our second child. “Like any parents, we were overjoyed. Like many parents, we were overwhelmed. “Like fewer parents, we weren’t confronted with the harsh reality of either spending those first few critical months with our baby or going back to work. “We knew we could take her home, and in that vitalstage, devote any and everything to our kids and to our family. “We knew that by doing so we wouldn’t have to make impossible choices about childcare, work, and medical care that so many have to make every single day. “No family should be faced with these decisions. She wrote: “I grew up on the .-dollar salad bar at Sizzler – it may have cost less back then– but what I do remember was the feeling: I knew how hard my parents worked to afford this because even at five bucks, eating out was something special, and I felt lucky.  “And as a Girl Scout, when my troop would go to dinner for a big celebration, it was back to that same salad bar or The Old Spaghetti Factory because that’s what those families could afford to do too. “I started workingat the age of . “I waited tables, babysat, and piece-mealed jobs together to cover odds and ends. “I worked all my le and saved when and where I could – but even that was a luxury – because usually it was about making ends meet and having enough to pay my rent and put gas in my car.” The former Suits actress, who signed off as “Meghan, The Duchess of Sussex”, concluded the letter, by writing: “If we’re going to create a new era of family-first policies, let’s make sure that includes a strong paid leave program for every American that’s guaranteed, accessible, and encouraged without stigma or penalty.  “I know how politically charged things can – and have – become.
